subject: Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... an ... not ... I ... will ... timed ... as ... ratio ... Then ... brain ... Well I figured this thread hasn t talked about JUnit in a while, so why not
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ron Jeffries <ronjeffries@X...> wrote:
> On Wednesday, October 1, 2003, at 7:56:17 PM, Matt wrote:
>
> > To be technical here, Temperature is not a ratio variable, it is
an
> > interval variable. There is no 'zero' in temperature so it is
not
> > correct to say it is going to be twice as cold tomorrow. And yes,
I
> > know there is 'absolute' zero but ask any statistician and he
will
> > tell you that using ratios with our normal temperature scales is
> > simply wrong. Using ratios with time works if you are using
timed
> > tests and define 'zero' as no time. Then yes, 5 minutes is twice
as
> > slow as 10 minutes. Before benchmarking make sure you have a
ratio
> > level variable if you want to express your results in ratios.
Then
> > you must define the zero point otherwise your ratios are
> > meaningless.
>
> I was only half as slow reading this as you were writing it, but my
brain
> got twice as hot ...
>

Well I figured this thread hasn't talked about JUnit in a while, so
why not throw some stats in there to mix things up a bit...
